message.content:
The phrase "can't see the forest for the trees" means that someone is unable to see the big picture because they are too focused on small details. It's like being so absorbed in individual trees that you fail to realize you're standing in a vast forest. 

In practical terms, this expression highlights an inability or unwillingness to grasp the overall situation, often leading to inadequate decisions based on incomplete understanding. To overcome this, it's essential for individuals and organizations alike to regularly step back and assess their objectives, progress, and contributions within broader contexts.

There is no established technique for metaphor improvement or transforming your mindset from merely seeing separate threads into embarking upon fortune-telling. This would require one analysis of specific methods dependent upon intended outcomes.

If what you meant was how can we improve our ability not only to look at details but also understand them as part of a larger context (seeing both details & big picture), I suggest following these steps:

1) Take regular breaks: Stepping away from work or any task occasionally helps clear your mind and regain perspective.
2) Seek input from others: Talking with colleagues, friends, or family members about your work may provide insights that help broaden your understanding of particular issues.
3) Practice visualization techniques: Visualize yourself “zooming out” when focusing on specifics; imagine a bird’s-eye view encompassing all aspects connected with those factors under scrutiny.
4) Maintain objectivity by continually asking questions concerning overarching purposes behind activities ranging across various projects/tasks subject areas—this aids seeing connections between seemingly disconnected parts thereof.
5) Develop strategic thinking skills through critical reflection exercises designed toward identifying main themes cutting swaths among myriad action items subsumed thereunder—a skill particularly invaluable amongst high-level decision-makers charged exercising
